comments.commentBody: Please do not equate the US with its government. They are quite distinct. Greenwald is a strong supporter of the US Constitution. He thinks, with some reason, that the US government has gone astray.

I think you meant to say "one of the good ex pats, living in Brazil," Mark, but your main point is well taken.  Obviously Greenwald is a "good guy."  He's just a bore who doesn't like America much.  Personally, I think he's a great American success story about reinvention of self.

Glenn Greenwald is a true American patriot, a defender of the principles on which the United States was founded. The Founding Fathers would have seen him as a worthy ally and fellow traveler. That he discomfits the current US regime is a measure of how far the US government has fallen short of the ideals of the Founding Fathers.

Glenn Greenwald himself is the most "nationalistic journalist." It's just the "nation" he favors is anyone but the US. He doesn't have a problem with "nationalistic journalist" in Britain, France or even Russia and China. He certainly doesn't have a problem with it in Brazil.

Does Bill Keller with all his experience, and all his proven skill, and in his position to know, really truly just not know how bad the content has become?

In this byplay with Greenwald, it reads as if Keller was clueless, as if the things Greenwald is saying have never occurred to Keller. That can't be. I don't believe it.

You need to think long and hard to explain why the single-payer system works perfectly fine (at least, more than 90% of the people are happy with it, and longer lifespan than stateside) in countries as different as Canada, Germany and Japan, while consuming much smaller share of GDP than in the U.S. - and will be a disaster here. And please don't tell that that's all because we pay for all the drug R&D in the world - first, it's not true, and second, all the drug expenses combined are less than 10% of our healthcare bill.

It's clear that Medicare for all would have been vastly simpler and more cost-effective than the Affordable Care Act. It's a shame that this option was never even presented to the Congress and the public for review. I recall, though, that Dr. Krugman was critical of candidate Obama's health care stance in 2008 because of Obama's dismissal of the single-payer option. As he almost always proves to be, Krugman was prescient.

In the short run, though, the task is to clean up the computer glitches and begin to implement the ACA. It's an improvement for many, and it's the system we've created.

In case you weren't paying attention during the health care debates (i.e, during that period after Mr. Obama's election when the Democrats controlled both houses of Congress). most of the naysayers on single-payer insurance were of the GOP persuasion.  Some of the Democratic outliers like Nelson and Lieberman are out of office now and Baucus has one foot out the door.  It would be good to see the President once again propose that Medicare-for-all be the law of the land and have Harry Reid bring it to the floor.  Sixty votes in the Senate would still be unlikely and a majority in the House would be impossible to achieve.  Even so, as questions about the ACA persist it would be instructive for Americans to see for themselves which party is firmly against universal health care. Let those who serve in government but are opposed to the very IDEA of government explain to their constituents why Medicare can serve the needs of seniors but not those of the rest of us.

The big lie peddled by the far right is that equal opportunity will blossom once government gets out of the way. Why don't more of us realize that corporate America is just waiting to pull working class Americans into stable middle-class careers if it weren't for onerous regulations, progressive taxation and access to a safety net? If Nik Wallenda can cross the Grand Canyon on faith alone, it should be good enough for the rest of us.

The poor reasoning is that no successful, industrialized nation in the world governs by the principles the GOP champions.

So we should immediately transfer to this system.

I have heard all the arguments you have made before and there are evils to single payer. Remember, that Medicare is different in conception, it is an insurance policy that you pay into all of your working life. Even if your contribution doesn't approach your benefit there is still the rationale that you have paid into it and received your benefit after a full life of working. Most of these single payer systems ration care and dilute the quality. Moreover, the incentive to improve outcomes is diminished. My father was on dialysis for 5 years at the age of 85. Most of these systems would have precluded him from receiving the treatment. Although we are paying the insurance company, what we are paying for is the efficiency gained by the profit motive. Remember, they are still required to give a level of care consistent with the new mandates. I am a Liberal, I support all of the mandates, a level of care that serves as a social safety net. But like many Liberals, you have discounted the principle of self reliance. I can't.
I agree Brooks is terrible, but your criticism is off-base. Brooks is an op-ed columnist. He doesn't pretend to be a journalist. IMHO, it is valuable to see other viewpoints, however slimy.

Actually, while I agree that it's nice to see everything printed, the fact is, Keller isn't stupid, and he really didn't have any other option. Greenwald doesn't mess around when it comes to bringing attention to those who selectively choose parts of interviews and facts, and when people have tried to leave important statements out of an interview or email exchange in the past, he has released all of the details to his readers. This not only provided context, but has proven to be quite revealing in terms of what some people or organizations have chosen not to publish.

In other words, Keller knew he didn't have much choice in the matter, as the full interview was likely to be revealed no matter what.

Karen,

David Brooks is the NYT's "Straw Conservative" kept on staff to "prove" the NYT is "fair and balanced" (NOT!). Nowhere outside of the NorthEast and not some places there either is he Conserative!

Brooks is not the issue. The issue is and has been proved by the Obama Administration, the Rich have a seat at the table no matter who is in Washington! Glenn claims he will report that fact!

I have to compliment Bill Keller for printing verbatim his exchange with Glenn Greenwald, when he very easily could have turned his column into another establishment smear job on a non-traditional journalist. (see the Julian Assange story by Keller from a few years ago, in which Assange's skipping and socks and personality quirks trumped his whistleblowing and leaks in the public interest.)

The conversational framing of this column is an indication that the Times is taking to heart some of the recent criticism about its proclivity to act as a mouthpiece for the government, too often giving unwarranted anonymity and protection to elected officials, the better to spread their propaganda.

Much of the credit for this seeming turnabout is also due to the Times's outstanding public editor, Margaret Sullivan. She has been at the forefront of criticizing everything from the paper's coverage of drone strikes, to the NSA revelations, and yes -- even David Brooks, when in a recent column he referred to mixed-race families as "mutts." (he said it was OK, because biracial people sometimes refer to themselves as mutts.)

Brooks had also attempted to pettily marginalize Edward Snowden as a misfit with girlfriend issues as soon as Glenn Greenwald broke the first NSA story. If anything, Glenn's criticism of him is way too mild. Brooks is a menace in centrist clothing, and a disgrace to journalism.
Sadly the very serious people here believe we need a centrist party, not one of the left.
Considering the happiness of Scandinavian countries, socialism looks OK to me.  To head off any rants, I am a retired colonel, Vietnam vet, with children who served in the idiotic fiasco of Iraq.

The father of Canadian universal medicare was a Baptist minister named Tommy Douglas who led the socialist party (NDP) to power in Saskatchewan. He was recently named the greatest Canadian in a contest on the public broadcaster CBC.

In his campaigns Douglas used the story of Mouseland, a story very applicable to American politics today. Mouseland had a parliament and two parties, the Black Cats and the White Cats. The two parties battled back and forth for the votes of the mice, making all sorts of promises about how good they could make life for mice, spinning stories of mouse justice and liberty.

But when they got the votes of the mice, they would eat the mice. The mice elected the White Cats, who promised cheese, but got eaten. And then they elected the reformist black cats who promptly kept on eating mice. They mice tried a coalition of black and white cats. Same result.

Then one brave mouse stood up and suggested they elect a Mouse Party. "Socialist!" the Very Serious Mice called her. But some mice thought it worth a try, and they put out some candidates. The cats told the mice they didn't understand free markets. But eventually the mice won, and the cats stopped eating the mice.

The U.S. needs a Mouse Party. The Democrats are a big business, conservative party which needs a shock to its complacency. Something like a Tea Party of the left.

I will be furious if the government makes the same mistake again.
And, immigration concerns should not be a priority at this time. The US needs more fiscal stimulus to help its citizens recover from the 2008 financial debacle.
Let's hope that Democrats stand up for our own poor citizens as well.
I'm sorry to say that many Republicans stand up only for themselves and their wallets. I wish it were not so, but it is.

It is not a civil right to cross the border illegally flouting the laws of the country you seek to make your home. It is not a civil right to have unlimited numbers of children in a world that is already overpopulated, with perhaps a billion people worldwide suffering from intermittent hunger.

It is not a civil right for octomom to have fertility treatments so that she can have eight more children when she already has six.

Civil right are time-dependent. When the world was sparsely populated, when there was an open frontier, when resources were plentiful, it may have made sense to allow men and women to have as many children as they want.

No more.

People need to accept a new morality. It is wrong for anyone to have more than two children in an overpopulated world. That applies to millionaires as well as the poor. But in particular it applies to citizens of foreign countries who come to the US to have large families, the children becoming automatic US citizens because of our badly designed laws.

Illegal immigrants selfishly rob from America's poor. Illegal immigration is one of the causes of high unemployment for unskilled workers. for state budgets going into the red because of so many K12 students, of health care that becomes more expensive, because the immigrants are treated for free, with costs passed on to everyone else.

Let's hope the Republicans stand up for an end to unsustainable population growth which is driving down American living standards.
An anecdote which even if true does not represent reality. I think you made this up. I don't believe you.

Sure. All my elderly mom's medical bills are paid by Medicare for the most part. Not all that much really but they accept it. Her supplemental plan kicks in and pays what little Medicare doesn't. I guess that's why the hospitals and docs around here don't mind seeing her. They know they'll at least get paid. But Medicare always pays about 80% of the reduced bill. So your numbers look about right. What's your complaint again? Private insurance always negotiate the rest of bill down too. The patient doesn't pay that difference.

Oh mom's Medicare premium is about $100/mo and her supplement $300/mo. Yet Medicare pays most of the bill. Who's cheaper now?
Steve C I will just repeat what I said. In the instance that I am reporting, medicare paid four times as much. For the exact same procedure.

Medicare is not cheaper.

I am a tax accountant. Sadly. I had a client last year. She had two hip replacements. Both in 2012, six months apart. One paid by Medicare the other paid by private insurance. Same hospital, same doctor.

The hospital billed Medicare $49,000, wrote off $36,000, paid the hospital $12,500 and my client paid $500.

The private insurance? The hospital billed the private carrier $7,000, wrote off $4,100, paid the hospital $2,300 my client paid $600.

Medicare was paid $12,500; private insurance was paid $2,300. For the exact same surgery.

This is real life medicine. I have the bills, in hand.

Let us just dispense with this nonsense that "Medicare is cheaper."

It is not.

The controversy seems likely to continue, though. The indication that this is true is contained in this very article, in the caption of the photograph "Mr. Capa called 'the last man to die' in the war." If Mr. Capa meant this literally then it cannot possibly be true, as the German forces surrendered piecemeal well into May, including units on the Western Front. It can't be possible that the soldier pictured, killed in mid-April, was in fact the last man to die in the war. And, it's extremely improbable that any photographer would be able to find the last man killed and photograph him . The odds of winning the PowerBall lottery are probably better.

I take Capa's statement about "the last man" to mean that the photo is a representation, an interpretation, of the idea of the last man killed in the war. He is alone, no other signs of war around him. It is quiet, peaceful, and then he is struck and falls and as he lies dying on the floor he hears the shot that killed him, fired by an unseen foe who will melt away and the war will be over. Whether "Death of a ...Militiaman" was "real" or posed or a photo of a man who simply fell while running downhill, it still represents the idea of a man at the instant of death in battle.

I think it was Hemingway who said that the best fiction is more true than the facts. That's how I think of these two photographs.
I'm glad to hear that a recording was made, one that helps put the lie to the fabrication myth.

These companies are highly regulated, similar to how the US regulates public utility companies. For example, in many countries, HC insurance companies MUST pay out 90% of revenues for medical expenses of their customers.
